channel.name: Failed to derive correct actions issue

messages.content:
`lottery.reducer.fetchActions()` started to throw error while reconstructing merkle list. Seems like some bug in o1js.
```
file:///Users/andrey/projects/L1-lottery/node_modules/.pnpm/o1js@1.3.1/node_modules/o1js/dist/node/lib/mina/fetch.js:437
            throw new Error(`Failed to derive correct actions hash for ${publicKey}.
                  ^

Error: Failed to derive correct actions hash for B62qk3U9ZUZ2a21T4thqhUgBvXM3xMyA1HtQBQ79unUHrytEVpNhtqm.
        Derived hash: 26200158804984732445947139995529844588985746703411535773945999629267519048333, expected hash: 806534191840875465837323299020552650224268402125665996458629125778783471442).
        All action hashes derived: [
  {
    "actions": [
      [
        "5",
        "5",
        "5",
        "1",
        "3",
        "9",
        "12956991225953906921841684099823101706501308776705520473434038962466907995970",
        "0",
        "4",
        "0"
      ]
    ],
    "hash": "21563203018944556031484929034248090238281413514617142803130850492739038376409"
  },
  ...
]
        Please try a different Archive Node API endpoint.
        
    at file:///Users/andrey/projects/L1-lottery/node_modules/.pnpm/o1js@1.3.1/node_modules/o1js/dist/node/lib/mina/fetch.js:437:19
    at Array.forEach (<anonymous>)
    at Module.fetchActions (file:///Users/andrey/projects/L1-lottery/node_modules/.pnpm/o1js@1.3.1/node_modules/o1js/dist/node/lib/mina/fetch.js:409:20)
    at process.processTicksAndRejections (node:internal/process/task_queues:95:5)
    at async Module.fetchActions (file:///Users/andrey/projects/L1-lottery/node_modules/.pnpm/o1js@1.3.1/node_modules/o1js/dist/node/lib/mina/mina-instance.js:85:12)
```
Created an issue https://github.com/o1-labs/o1js/issues/1775 and proof of concept:
Script â€“ https://github.com/ZkNoid/L1-lottery/blob/main/scripts/bug_poc.ts

To reproduce:

```
git clone https://github.com/ZkNoid/L1-lottery
npm install
npm run build && node build/scripts/bug_poc.js
```

Previously this fetching worked. We think this may have something to do with uncle blocks in the network and the incorrect order of actions in the merkle list on the archive node
@gregor would be amaizing if you could check the issue

I've got the error below when I ran `bug_poc.js`. It seems private_constants.ts is missing.
```
> l1-lottery-contracts@0.7.13 build
> tsc && rollup build/src/index.js --file build/src/index.cjs --format cjs

src/PLottery.test.ts:36:39 - error TS2307: Cannot find module './private_constants' or its corresponding type declarations.

36 import { treasury, treasuryKey } from './private_constants';
                                         ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

src/Random/RandomManager.ts:13:26 - error TS2307: Cannot find module '../private_constants' or its corresponding type declarations.

13 import { treasury } from '../private_constants';
                            ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~


Found 2 errors in 2 files.

Errors  Files
     1  src/PLottery.test.ts:36
     1  src/Random/RandomManager.ts:13
```

You should wait some time, maybe one hour or two, for big number of actions, and this error will go away:
https://github.com/o1-labs/o1js/issues/1426#issuecomment-1938787799
@45930 I think this issue would be interesting for you to look into it https://github.com/o1-labs/Archive-Node-API/pull/102/files
It doesn't. Also it's very unreliable, this error may block the whole game
Can you try to switch from minascan to minaexpolorer endpoints and see if there is any difference in this case?
Also wanted to try this but minaexplorer archive node is down
Are you able to fetch events now from minascan devnet archive node by calling `const events = await zkApp.fetchEvents()`?
You can also try on mainnet putting fee 0.01 MINA
Events are fetching correctly
This issue occures time to time but when it occurs it blocks the whole game. If we redeploy on mainnet we'll need a time until the same issue happens

Interesting. For my contract, I can fetch events when I'm using  `await fetchEvents({ publicKey: contractAddress })` and receive `Gateway Time-out` when I use `const events = await zkApp.fetchEvents();` on devnet, on mainnet everything works.

The minascan devnet archive node was recently unable to get txs from the network due to ban bug issue, and maybe your effect with actions and my effect with events is related to it.
We have a theory that this may have something to do with uncle blocks and incorrect order of actions when chain is forked
Added issue 1777 https://github.com/o1-labs/o1js/issues/1777

When I was looking at this error, I've made a code that calculates actions hash to understand where the problem is:
https://github.com/dfstio/merkle-map-demo/blob/main/tests/base.test.ts#L192
Let me try it

You can also try to play with different values, including undefined, for 
`fromActionState` and `endActionState`

The problem is pin-pointed. There is an action that fails hash reconstruction if queried. The action state is `806534191840875465837323299020552650224268402125665996458629125778783471442`
If it's queried directly, request fails
```
    fromActionState: Field.from('23282384716759778041265197000989706423962846376707787360646691452073711502533'),
    endActionState: Field.from('806534191840875465837323299020552650224268402125665996458629125778783471442'),```
If all the actions before or after are queried â€“ they're fetched fine.
The action that broke hash reconstruction:
```
{
        "blockInfo": {
          "height": 331235,
          "stateHash": "3NKiWyPvUrvj23YrbLVAZjqLXosn4nPV5DummWoGvb8cccRnp2ah",
          "parentHash": "3NKrDMvWrMuAEj4u9dnzMqRPEt83ysqSxMMJrFK3pyU3jfKKQd6C",
          "ledgerHash": "jxjwB539SXSH4B4shQCYM7yKBuYTzLFU81fw24xmLUtN3NeoMPL",
          "chainStatus": "canonical",
          "timestamp": "1722003300000",
          "globalSlotSinceHardfork": 51705,
          "globalSlotSinceGenesis": 497565,
          "distanceFromMaxBlockHeight": 419
        },
        "actionData": [
          ...
        ],
        "actionState": {
          "actionStateOne": "806534191840875465837323299020552650224268402125665996458629125778783471442",
          "actionStateTwo": "23282384716759778041265197000989706423962846376707787360646691452073711502533",
          "actionStateThree": "23491400111067065425071221678721345775402470818894691431546365209464447649194",
          "actionStateFour": "6544874369521994745834099982041794305879681779682444143652167535497851833950",
          "actionStateFive": "8570738680321668743272257331919516722617369644408552740875789197789679512446"
        },
        "transactionInfo": null
      },
```

The timestamp of this block 331235 is 26.07.2024 UTC 14:15
@boray  The archive node was banned shortly before that:
```
/ip4/103.50.33.192/tcp/8302/p2p/12D3KooWK8CL1rzFQVqTPPU28oRb2aWGfp3gUdLxht1um79Sdssn, -0.6465, Banned_until 2024-07-25 17:52:23.471135Z
```
and B62qk3U9ZUZ2a21T4thqhUgBvXM3xMyA1HtQBQ79unUHrytEVpNhtqm sent txs shortly after the ban was lifted:
https://minascan.io/devnet/tx/5Ju9N54xwuFFzFhraRMzAdAxjHsmLakE8F8Uxv9cwWqt2A2bg4Rc?type=zk-tx
At that time, the data at the archive node maybe was not  up-to-date
We deployed the new instance and it fails as well 😭

Maybe you should try to use fromActionState, which is set to the first action hash, as a workaround? However, to make it production-grade, the archive node bugs should be removed. Before it is made, it is better to use IPFS for off-chain storage.
This doesn't work. There is also a strange event that breaks reconstruction in queried

```
{
        "blockInfo": {
          "height": 331896,
          "stateHash": "3NKiFBjvNzU4Vi9DpGsT6tXcUmj78Ea1Mt79yeodZyYpEPfaagW2",
          "parentHash": "3NLenZqGbN1dJhqUcdCUyycb68o86Wxcai4ArprjHMpDxSGBTzs8",
          "ledgerHash": "jwxaoq88DLFLHk7UPrrzPQRM46ApRW22DDZ6NHfyYqEaDTAwsEp",
          "chainStatus": "pending",
          "timestamp": "1722184200000",
          "globalSlotSinceHardfork": 52710,
          "globalSlotSinceGenesis": 498570,
          "distanceFromMaxBlockHeight": 88
        },
        "actionData": [
          ...
        ],
        "actionState": {
          "actionStateOne": "11375103874676752843679023104000480492556696883691245222561397315560913034859",
          "actionStateTwo": "6477244058198781390337659736747417300726377772583277594433212424789142543557",
          "actionStateThree": "3846811119856138811001824594113061749458057358141113414738602043625242882698",
          "actionStateFour": "18887616978821033182472704488364221586840282818339831459651139991712727557725",
          "actionStateFive": "4802013358285588978585000649771868009042108281002852520777292723914451820355"
        },
        "transactionInfo": null
      },
```
The current alternatives are IPFS, Celestia, and Arweave. I believe that the best outcome would be for all off-chain solutions to work, giving developers a choice.
How can they be used to fetch actions?

You don't need actions of archive node if you use them, but the code would be much more complicated than in off-chain examples by o1js. Basically, you should maintain Merkle Map/Tree there and keep the root on chain, but there are many details as usual.

Example of approx. 1000 txs sent:
https://minascan.io/devnet/account/B62qoYeVkaeVimrjBNdBEKpQTDR1gVN2ooaarwXaJmuQ9t8MYu9mDNS/txs?type=zk-acc
To keep track of actions we need to somehow fetch them correctly
It is hard to do now, but you can try to build a code with pagination and error recovery that will do it.
I'm not sure it's possible to detect the source of error using code

Well, what you can do is use several sources of data - archive node, events, blackberry and then try to recover the info if at least one of those sources works. You can also fetch events in 4 different ways, so you can build error handling around it. Not easy, but it can work if you absolutely need to use actions.

You need to develop a custom contract for it to make sure that it emits all the necessary redundant data.
I think it may be a deeper issue on Mina. Actions may be stored incorrectly in some cases

Example for events:
zkApp.fetchEvents()
fetchEvents()
Mina.fetchEvents()
blockberry

All 4 give different results on devnet now; some fail, and some do not.
I've checked they all use fetchEvents under the hood
It is being investigated now and will be fixed soon I believe if it is the case
But they put different start/stop params and it makes the difference, also there is inconsistency in the params required inside o1js
In this case it's clear that queuing the one strange event brokes the hash reconstruction. Start / end params won't impact the issue
Can't find a way to query actions on blockberry
I understand that there is no direct query, txs should be analyzed to build it.
Pin-pointed the issue even more. The problem occurs when 3+ actions are dispatched within one block. Two works fine, but when there are 3+ transactions to our zkApp it fails
Here are the transactions to our old zkApp in the block with strange action
Transactions to the new zkApp in the block with strange action
So when it becomes 3+, all fails
Seems that it's another issue. They discussed limit per action data. But we have some limit per actions number in block

Reproduced this on lightnet. We'll prepare and share the repo soon. The issue is veery strange. The combination of using this.sender.getAndRequireSignature() passed to an action and 3+ actions sending in one block are the required components for issue reproduction

We made a repository for error reproduction. It can be reproduced on litenet
https://github.com/aii23/actions_issue_poc
Thank you guys!

Hey I am playing around with this and I think the signature thing is a red herring.  In your working example, the action is always the same one every time.  It's a static address.  If you update the example to use the address of the sender via input to the method, then it fails in the same way as the signature.
Interesting. Haven't you got an idea of what can be happening yet?
I do have an idea... Still doing some testing before I share more but I'll check back in soon!
Hey guys, hoping we have the fix here! https://github.com/o1-labs/o1js/pull/1784

embeds.title: Correcting order for actions occuring within the same block for the...
embeds.description: The community has raised this issue where their reducer cannot correctly derive the action hash given the response from the archive node.  This only happens when multiple actions are dispatched wit...

messages.content: Awesome! But we have one concern. Seems that issue is fixed with actions reversing. However when there was 2, not 3 events in block, the previous fetch worked fine. Now the 2 actions would be reversed and the expected order may be incorrect. Could you please confirm that your fix works for exact 2 actions in the same block?

I don't believe that 2 actions previously worked.  I used your script to test 1, 2, 3, and more actions per block and found that only 1 per block currently works.

The exception is when the actions happen to be the same action duplicated, because order will not matter then.  So I believe that you successfully reduced 2 actions in one block before, but that it was the same action twice.  You can see for yourself by testing with your script `lightnet_reproduce.sh`.  If you set the line `node build/src/call_dispatch.js brokenstruct_lightnet 1`, the script will work.  If you make it `node build/src/call_dispatch.js brokenstruct_lightnet 2`, then it will fail.
Seems legit. Thanks for the fix!
If anyone can help to merge the pr faster and publish the version with fix on npm it will help us a lot
Could you try your patched fetch and the original one on B62qmbX7xkXxLhKQpi4iabLzEtzyXi9uA5pFU1PbACoXCMt6DEC3t1g address on devnet?

First it was broken with the error. Then I applied the patch you provided and launched our backend. After some time of work is started to throw derive issues. Then I noticed that previous not patched fetch started working with it while the patched one is now fails
